issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
Regarding the excel sheet: How do your rectified images achieve a higher framerate than the raw images? 

Maybe your graphics card is too weak? The range for multisense cameras got upped from 100 to 300 and task1 is the largest one so it would explain a lower framerate with slower graphics cards. I'm getting 29.x Hz in all worlds (and this <1Hz missing is only due to ROS publishing/throttling).
content.html:
Regarding the excel sheet: How do your rectified images achieve a higher framerate than the raw images?

Maybe your graphics card is too weak? The range for multisense cameras got upped from 100 to 300 and task1 is the largest one so it would explain a lower framerate with slower graphics cards. I'm getting 29.x Hz in all worlds (and this <1Hz missing is only due to ROS publishing/throttling).

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
Each measurement was taken from a unique simulation instead of taking them all at once from the same sim (which is what I probably should have done).

Regarding my graphics card, I'm running on an NVIDIA Tesla C2075.

Which changeset are you currently using? I am running 2011:c7102caafb3f.
content.html:
Each measurement was taken from a unique simulation instead of taking them all at once from the same sim (which is what I probably should have done).

Regarding my graphics card, I'm running on an NVIDIA Tesla C2075.

Which changeset are you currently using? I am running 2011:c7102caafb3f.

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
I was testing using drcsim_2.5 branch (so ce6114c was the last change) and an NVIDIA GTX 680 ... the camera ranges recently got increased from 100 to 300 so my guess is that the C2075 might not be able render two 800x800 images at 30Hz enough with the increased far range clipping. Did you run gazebo headless or with GUI? Do frame rates go up when using no GUI / making the window as small as possible or minimizing it?

OSRF tested the change of 100 to 300 far clipping range before merging it and didn't observe any change but I don't know what machines they tested it on.
content.html:
I was testing using drcsim_2.5 branch (so ce6114c was the last change) and an NVIDIA GTX 680 ... the camera ranges recently got increased from 100 to 300 so my guess is that the C2075 might not be able render two 800x800 images at 30Hz enough with the increased far range clipping. Did you run gazebo headless or with GUI? Do frame rates go up when using no GUI / making the window as small as possible or minimizing it?

OSRF tested the change of 100 to 300 far clipping range before merging it and didn't observe any change but I don't know what machines they tested it on.

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
Running headless has improved the simulation to real-time factor (so I'm getting a couple more frames per second real-time), but I'm still only seeing a 15 Hz publishing rate in simulation time.

I'm confused as to why this even possible. Shouldn't the cameras always run at 30 Hz in simulation time, with the rate you get in real-time being hardware dependent?
content.html:
Running headless has improved the simulation to real-time factor (so I'm getting a couple more frames per second real-time), but I'm still only seeing a 15 Hz publishing rate in simulation time.

I'm confused as to why this even possible. Shouldn't the cameras always run at 30 Hz in simulation time, with the rate you get in real-time being hardware dependent?

content.raw:
Hmm I'm not really sure what changed but I'm seeing the same issue now as well. Only getting 13-14fps in task1.

edit: weird, even downgrading to ``gazebo_1.6`` + ``drcsim_2.4`` doesn't bring it back to normal ... 3 days ago i still had full fps with latest gazebo and drcsim, so it has to be something else I suppose. The only other thing I've changed recently was to downgrade from Ogre 1.8.1 to 1.7.4 (default Ubuntu 12.04 package).

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
I just upgraded back to Ogre 1.8.1 and I'm getting the full 30fps again. 
So now there's two issues: a) the GPU LIDAR + heightmaps don't work with 1.8.1 on my PC, b) it seems like 1.8.1 is required for 30Hz, at least on my PC. 

Can you check whether it works at ~30fps for you when compiling against Ogre 1.8.1?
content.html:
I just upgraded back to Ogre 1.8.1 and I'm getting the full 30fps again. So now there's two issues: a) the GPU LIDAR + heightmaps don't work with 1.8.1 on my PC, b) it seems like 1.8.1 is required for 30Hz, at least on my PC.

Can you check whether it works at ~30fps for you when compiling against Ogre 1.8.1?

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
So ``pkg-config CEGUI --modversion`` and/or ``pkg-config CEGUI-OGRE --modversion`` don't show anything either I presume? Make sure CEGUI is installed correctly such that pkg-config is able to find it (there should be a ``CEGUI-OGRE.pc`` file in ``/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig/``).
Maybe you forgot to run ``sudo make install``? :)
content.html: So pkg-config CEGUI --modversion and/or pkg-config CEGUI-OGRE --modversion don't show anything either I presume? Make sure CEGUI is installed correctly such that pkg-config is able to find it (there should be a CEGUI-OGRE.pc file in /usr/local/lib/pkgconfig/). Maybe you forgot to run sudo make install? :)

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw: pkg-config returns 9999.0 for both and the .pc files are also both in /usr/lib/pkgconfig (I installed everything in /usr instead of /usr/local). I have cegui-0.7.9 installed now, perhaps I'll try 0.7.7.
content.html: pkg-config returns 9999.0 for both and the .pc files are also both in /usr/lib/pkgconfig (I installed everything in /usr instead of /usr/local). I have cegui-0.7.9 installed now, perhaps I'll try 0.7.7.

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
@ichen @nkoenig any idea whether this is "normal" behaviour or "just" specific to our machines? We also just tested on a different computer (similar hardware though) with gazebo+drcsim debian package installation and it has the same low framerate, so not just specific to custom source compilation.

If the GPU lidar would work with heightmaps with Ogre 1.8.1 I'd propose to upgrade to 1.8.1 (probably non-trivial though as it's not available as debian package I think), but right now it's more of a lose-lose situation. :-|
content.html:
@ichen @nkoenig any idea whether this is "normal" behaviour or "just" specific to our machines? We also just tested on a different computer (similar hardware though) with gazebo+drcsim debian package installation and it has the same low framerate, so not just specific to custom source compilation.

If the GPU lidar would work with heightmaps with Ogre 1.8.1 I'd propose to upgrade to 1.8.1 (probably non-trivial though as it's not available as debian package I think), but right now it's more of a lose-lose situation. :-|

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
We were able to reproduce this, it seems like vsync is on by default on some nvidia drivers which impacted the framerate. Turn it off by going to nvidia-settings -> X Screen 0 -> OpenGL Settings, and uncheck Sync to VBlank

Let me know if that works for you
content.html:
We were able to reproduce this, it seems like vsync is on by default on some nvidia drivers which impacted the framerate. Turn it off by going to nvidia-settings -> X Screen 0 -> OpenGL Settings, and uncheck Sync to VBlank

Let me know if that works for you

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
Hmm we tested on 3 different systems and we're getting different behaviour on every machine while running the same graphics card. 

My system with default Ogre: ~15fps on every task (didn't test vsync here as i'm running 1.8.1 right now which doesn't suffer from this problem).

system2: low fps on every task, unchecking Sync to VBlank doesn't change anything.

system3: low fps on task1, normal fps on task2 and 3 (3 uses the same grass plane as task 1) - unchecking Sync to VBlank doesn't change fps.
content.html:

system2: low fps on every task, unchecking Sync to VBlank doesn't change anything.

system3: low fps on task1, normal fps on task2 and 3 (3 uses the same grass plane as task 1) - unchecking Sync to VBlank doesn't change fps.

Upgrading to OGRE 1.8.1 fixed FPS in Task1.

issue.title: Low frame rates from MultisenseSL cameras in VRC Task1

content.raw:
I just tested this on another machine, and got interesting results: 

* Task 1: ~11-12fps w/ Vsync, ~8-9 w/o VSync 
* Task 2  ~29 w/ vsync 28-29 w/o vsync 
* Task 3 ~ 29 w/ vsync ~13-15 w/o vsync 

So it looks like disabling VSync causes worse performance than leaving it enabled. 
This test was done using Gazebo/DRCSim debian packages. Graphics Card was a GTX 680.
content.html:
I just tested this on another machine, and got interesting results:

  • Task 1: ~11-12fps w/ Vsync, ~8-9 w/o VSync
  • Task 2 ~29 w/ vsync 28-29 w/o vsync
  • Task 3 ~ 29 w/ vsync ~13-15 w/o vsync

So it looks like disabling VSync causes worse performance than leaving it enabled. This test was done using Gazebo/DRCSim debian packages. Graphics Card was a GTX 680.
